awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Understanding cooperation through the zero-error relay channel
awd_abstract_narration:
The research seeks to obtain the zero-error capacity a fundamental performance limit quantifying the number of messages that may be reliably communicated with no error of the primitive relay channel. In this channel, a source communicates with a destination in the presence of an out-of-band relay. Understanding how the source and relay may cooperate in communicating messages is interesting theoretically as the relay channel capacity has been open for over 40 years.  The research looks at the zero-error capacity, which differs from the more commonly studied small-error capacity, and leads to an unexplored combinatorial problem involving new relaying "compression" graphs. Progress in understanding how to cooperate from a mathematical, structural perspective is expected to be made by attacking the relay channel from this novel combinatorial angle. Understanding how to best relay is important in extending coverage of, or adding reliability to, wireless networks. Relaying is a part of existing standards such as 802.16j, 802.11ah, and 4G LTE Advanced.  The PI's outreach and educational efforts focus on remaining active in "women in science" retention and recruiting events and broadening awareness of information theory through non-specialist talks and tutorials. 

Technically, the research  will first determine when the zero-error capacity of the primitive relay channel is non-zero. When the capacity is positive, the structure of the graphs that characterize the overall capacity  of the primitive relay channel and how to best cooperate will be sought. These are expected to be difficult-to-compute combinatorial quantities; the goal will then be to simplify the expressions for certain classes of channels, and to understand the properties of these graphs as a function of the block length and number of nodes.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported research on the zero-error capacity of networks. The information theoretic capacity of a network generally refers to the number of messages that may be communicated from one or more sources to one or more destinations in a network, in the asymptotic limit as the number of channel uses (or delay) is let to grow to infinity and the probability of error (for probabilistically modeled noisy or interfering channels) is required to vanish, or become arbitrarily small. This has generally been well studied; much less studied is the zero-error capacity of networks, where the goal is again communication between nodes in a network but now we require the probability of error to be exactly zero rather than asymptotically vanishing. This renders the problem combinatorial rather than probabilistic and is generally more challenging. It also provides firm guarantees that no error will be made, important for a variety of applications which do not tolerate any error.  The funded research looked at the almost unstudied problem of the zero-error capacity of networks, and 1) obtained positivity conditions for many classes of networks, including the relay, the multiple-access, and broadcast, and the interference channels. We also 2) obtained zero-error capacity bounds for  the primitive relay channel, the one-way channel with noisy feedback, and the two-way channel. In particular, for the primitive relay channel, we devised a new and optimal (in a well defined sense) relaying scheme termed ``color-and-forward’’ in which the relay colors a specially defined ``relaying compression graph’’ and forwards a minimal graph-theoretic coloring to the destination. For the one-way channel with noisy, rather than the well-studied noiseless, feedback, we again obtained bounds on the zero-error capacity of such channels. Here a transmitter node wishes to communicate to a destination node, and this communication may be enhanced by feedback, or a link between the destination node and the transmitter node. In information theory, most results have assumed this feedback link to be idealized, providing the transmitter with the output the destination sees exactly. In our work we have assumed the feedback link is either noisy (and that the destination can actively decide what to transmit over this link), or is noiseless but rate limited (can only send a few bits of information over it) — much more realistic assumptions. We then obtained variable-length coding schemes which achieve zero-error over such channels. Again, such results are important not only to advance our theoretical understanding of these mathematical problems, but for providing bounds on which is possible in practice when we require exactly zero-error, or extremely high reliability communication. 

This grant has supported the training of two Ph.D. students and one post-doctoral researcher in electrical and computer engineering; the post-doctoral researcher is now working in research and development in the American tech industry. Our work has been published and presented at top international conference in the field. The principal investigator has been particularly active in leading and participating in events that support the recruitment and retention of women in engineering.
